title:
Large Induced Subgraphs of Bounded Degree in Outerplanar and Planar
  Graphs

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we study the following question. Let $\mathcal{G}$ be a family of planar graphs and let $k \geq 3$ be an integer. What is the largest value $f_{k}(n)$ such that every $n$-vertex graph in $\mathcal{G}$ has an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with $f_{k}(n)$ vertices? Similar questions, in which one seeks a large induced forest, or a large induced linear forest, or a large induced $d$-degenerate graph, rather than a large induced graph of bounded degree, have been studied for decades and have given rise to some of the most fascinating and elusive conjectures in Graph Theory. We tackle our problem when $\mathcal{G}$ is the class of the outerplanar graphs or the class of the planar graphs. In both cases, we provide upper and lower bounds on the value of $f_{k}(n)$. For example, we prove that every $n$-vertex planar graph has an induced subgraph with degree at most 3 and with $\frac{2 n}{19}>0.384 n$ vertices, and that there exist $n$-vertex planar graphs whose largest induced subgraph with degree at most 3 has $\frac{4 n}{7}+O(1)<0.572 n+O(1)$ vertices.


2012 ACM Subject Classification Theory of computation $\rightarrow$ Design and analysis of algorithms; Mathematics of computing $\rightarrow$ Combinatorics; Mathematics of computing $\rightarrow$ Graph theory

Keywords and phrases Induced graphs, planar graphs, outerplanar graphs, degree, treewidth
Funding This research was supported, in part, by MUR of Italy (PRIN Project no. 2022ME9Z78 NextGRAAL).

## I Introduction

The study of induced subgraphs has a central role in Graph Theory. As a prominent example, establishing the truth of the Albertson and Berman conjecture [1, 2], stating that every $n$-vertex planar graph contains an induced forest with at least $\frac{n}{2}$ vertices, is one of the most famous and frequently mentioned (see, e.g., $[5,8,13,14,26,23,24,27,29,30,32]$ ) open problems in Graph Theory. The conjectured bound $\frac{n}{2}$ is the best possible [1]. The best known lower bound is $\frac{2 n}{3}$, which comes from the acyclic 5 -colorability of planar graphs [7]. Other popular related conjectures state that every $n$-vertex bipartite planar graph has an induced forest with at least $\frac{5 n}{8}$ vertices [1] and that every $n$-vertex planar graph has an induced linear forest with at least $\frac{4 n}{9}$ vertices [27]. In the former case, the best known lower bound is $\left\lceil\frac{4 n+3}{7}\right\rceil$ [32], while in the latter case it is $\left\lceil\frac{n}{3}\right\rceil$ [28].

Combinatorial problems on induced graphs usually have the following form: Given a class $\mathcal{G}$ of $n$-vertex graphs, what is the largest function $f(n)$ such that every graph in $\mathcal{G}$ has an induced subgraph satisfying certain properties? Since in a clique one cannot find any induced subgraph other than a clique, the class $\mathcal{G}$ usually contains sparse graphs - most often $\mathcal{G}$ is the class of the $n$-vertex planar graphs or a subclass of it. More specifically, research on this topic has addressed the problem of determining the maximum size of: (i) an induced forest that one is guaranteed to find in a planar graph $[1,2,30]$, in an outerplanar graph [19], in a 2-outerplanar graph [8], in a planar graph with given girth $[3,13,16,23,24,29]$, in a graph with bounded treewidth [10], or in a cubic graph $[6,21,31]$; (ii) an induced linear forest that one is guaranteed to find in a planar graph [27, 28], in an outerplanar graph [27],

![table_0](table_0)

Table 1 Summary of the best known coefficients of the linear term for $k=3$.
or in a planar graph with given girth [14]; (iii) a $k$-degenerate induced graph that one is guaranteed to find in a planar graph [15, 18, 26]; and (iv) an induced matching that one is guaranteed to find in a planar graph with degree at most 3 [20].

In this paper, we study the maximum size of an induced graph of bounded degree that one is guaranteed to find in an outerplanar graph or in a planar graph. It was surprising to us, given that the degree is one of the most important, natural, and used graph parameters, that this problem has not been studied systematically before, to the best of our knowledge. A set of vertices which induces a graph of degree at most $k$ in a graph $G$ is sometimes called a $k$-stable set [17]. Our results are as follows.

- We show that every $n$-vertex outerplanar graph has an induced subgraph with degree at most 3 and with at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices, an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with at least $\frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5} n$ vertices, for any even integer $k \geq 4$, and an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with at least $\frac{2 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3} n$ vertices, for any odd integer $k \geq 5$. On the other hand, for any integer $k \geq 3$, there exists an $n$-vertex outerplanar graph, in fact an $n$-vertex outerpath, such that any induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ has at most $\frac{k-1}{k} n+O(1)$ vertices. The last bound is tight for the class of the $n$-vertex outerpaths.
- We show that every $n$-vertex planar graph has an induced subgraph with degree at most 3 and with at least $\frac{5}{13} n$ vertices, an induced subgraph with degree at most 4 and with at least $\frac{27}{59} n$ vertices, and, for any integer $k \geq 5$, an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with at least $\frac{k-2}{k+1} n$ vertices. On the other hand, for any integer $k \geq 3$, there exists an $n$-vertex planar graph such that any induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ has at most $\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+O(1)$ vertices and an $n$-vertex planar graph such that any induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ has at most $\frac{k+3}{k+4} n+O(1)$ vertices.

Table 1 shows the coefficients of the linear terms in the size of the induced subgraphs of degree at most 3 that we can find in the considered graph classes.

Related work. Although, as far as we know, the question of determining the maximum size of an induced graph of bounded degree that one is guaranteed to find in an outerplanar graph or in a planar graph was not addressed explicitly before, some results from the literature have an implication or a relationship to our problem.

- Fountoulakis, Kang, and McDiarmid [17] studied the maximum size of an induced subgraph of bounded degree that one is expected to find in a random graph.
- A $(c, k)$-defective coloring of a graph is a coloring of the vertices with $c$ colors such that each vertex $v$ has at most $k$ neighbors with the same color as $v$. Since the vertices in each color class induce a graph whose degree is bounded by $k$, the existence of a $(c, k)$-defective coloring for a graph $G$ implies the existence of a set of $\frac{n}{c}$ vertices that induce a subgraph of $G$ with degree at most $k$. Cowen, Cowen, and Woodall [11] proved that every outerplanar graph has a (2,2)-defective coloring and that every planar graph has a (3,2)-defective coloring. These results imply the existence of sets $\frac{n}{3}$ and $\frac{n}{3}$ of vertices in an $n$-vertex outerplanar or planar graph, respectively, that induce graphs with degree at most $k$. Our lower bounds are larger than these values, already for $k=3$ in which they are $\frac{2}{3} n$ and $\frac{5}{13} n$, respectively. See [33] for many more results on $(c, k)$-defective colorings.

- Linear forests have degree at most 2, hence the size of an induced linear forest that one is guaranteed to find in an $n$-vertex outerplanar graph (the optimal size $\lceil\frac{4 n+2}{2}\rceil$ was established by Pelsmajer [27]) or in an $n$-vertex planar graph (the best known lower bound $\lceil\frac{n}{2}\rceil$ is due to Poh [28]) is a lower bound for the size of an induced graph with degree at most $k$, for any integer $k \geq 3$, that one is guaranteed to find in an $n$-vertex outerplanar or planar graph, respectively. Our lower bounds are larger than these values, already for $k=3$ in which they are $\frac{2}{3} n$ and $\frac{5}{15} n$, respectively.
- Chappell and Pelsmajer [10] proved that every $n$-vertex graph with treewidth $t$ contains an induced forest with degree at most $k$ and with at least $\lceil\frac{2 k n+2}{t k+k+1}\rceil$ vertices. This provides a lower bound of $\lceil\frac{2 k n+2}{3 k+1}\rceil$ on the size of an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ that one is guaranteed to find in an $n$-vertex outerplanar graph. Our lower bounds are larger than $\lceil\frac{2 k n+2}{3 k+1}\rceil$ for any $k \geq 3$ (and sufficiently large $n$ ).
- Chappell and Pelsmajer [10] also proved (and attributed the result to Chappell, Gimbel, and Hartman) that every $n$-vertex forest contains an induced forest with degree at most $k$ and with at least $\lceil\frac{k+1}{k+2} n\rceil$ vertices. This bound is the best possible.
- Bose, Dujmović, and Wood [9] considered the following problem. Let $\mathcal{G}_{n, w}$ be the family of the $n$-vertex graphs with treewidth $w$, where $n \geq 2 w+1$. For given integers $0 \leq t \leq w$ and $k \geq 2 w$, what is the largest size of an induced graph that one is guaranteed to find in every graph $G$ in $\mathcal{G}_{n, w}$ such that the treewidth of the induced graph is at most $t$ and the degree of its vertices in $G$ is at most $k$ ? Note their stronger requirement about the degree in the given graph, rather than in the induced graph. They provided a bound for this problem which implies that every $n$-vertex outerplanar graph $G$ (in fact, every graph with treewidth 2) has a subset of at least $\frac{k-3}{k-1} n$ vertices whose degree in $G$ is at most $k$. This lower bound is weaker than our lower bounds for every integer $k \geq 3$.
- Knauer and Ueckerdt [22] considered the following problem. For given integers $w \geq 1$ and $c \geq 1$, what is the largest size of an induced graph that one is guaranteed to find in every graph of treewidth at most $w$ such that each connected component of the induced graph has at most $c$ vertices? They provided a $\frac{c}{w+c+1} n$ lower bound and a $\frac{c}{w+c} n$ upper bound for this problem. Their results imply (by setting $c=k+1$ ) a $\frac{k+1}{w+k+2} n$ lower bound for the size of an induced graph of degree at most $k$ that one is guaranteed to find in every graph of treewidth at most $w$. In particular, for outerplanar graphs this yields a $\frac{k+1}{k+4} n$ lower bound, which is weaker than our lower bounds for every integer $k \geq 3$.
- Finally, as mentioned above, the size of $k$-degenerate subgraphs in planar graphs, for $k=2$ [15], $k=3$ [18], and $k=4$ [26] has been studied. A lower bound on the size of an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ is also a lower bound on the size of a $k$-degenerate induced subgraph, and an upper bound for the latter size is an upper bound for the former one. The upper and lower bounds in $[18,26]$ are in fact larger than ours.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we give some preliminaries; in Section 3 and Section 4, we present our results for outerplanar graphs and planar graphs, respectively; finally, in Section 5, we conclude and present some open problems.

sections.text:
# 2 Preliminaries 

We use standard terminology in Graph Theory [12]. For a graph $G$, we let $V(G)$ and $E(G)$ be its vertex and edge sets, respectively. For a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$, we denote by $G[\mathcal{I}]$ the induced subgraph of $G$, that is, the graph whose vertex set is $\mathcal{I}$ and whose edge set consists of every edge $(u, v) \in E(G)$ such that $u, v \in \mathcal{I}$. The degree of a vertex $v$ is the number of its incident

edges and the degree of a graph is the maximum degree of any of its vertices. A set $\mathcal{D} \subseteq V(G)$ is a dominating set if every vertex of $G$ is in $\mathcal{D}$ or is adjacent to a vertex in $\mathcal{D}$.

A drawing of a graph maps each vertex to a point in the plane and each edge to a Jordan arc between the points representing the end-vertices of the edge. A drawing is planar if no two edges cross, except at common end-vertices. A planar graph is a graph that admits a planar drawing. A planar drawing partitions the plane into connected regions, called faces; the unique unbounded face is the outer face, while the other faces are internal. A planar drawing is outerplanar if every vertex is incident to the outer face. An outerplanar graph is a graph that admits an outerplanar drawing. A maximal outerplanar graph is an outerplanar graph such that adding any edge to it results in a graph that contains a multiple edge or is not outerplanar. Consider a maximal outerplanar graph $G$ and observe that $G$ has a unique outerplanar drawing, up to a reflection and a homeomorphism of the plane. We call outerplane embedding, and denote it by $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, the topological information associated with such a drawing. Without loss of information, one can think that $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is just an outerplanar drawing of $G$. Observe that the outer face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is delimited by a Hamiltonian cycle, while the internal faces are delimited by cycles with 3 vertices. An edge $u v$ of $G$ splits $G$ into two outerplanar graphs, namely the subgraphs of $G$ that are induced by the vertices encountered when walking in clockwise and counter-clockwise direction along the outer face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ from $u$ to $v$. These are called $u v$-split subgraphs of $G$. The vertices $u$ and $v$, as well as the edge $u v$, belong to both $u v$-split subgraphs of $G$. If $u v$ is incident to the outer face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, then one of these subgraphs is just the edge $u v$ and the other one is $G$. We define the distance in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ between two distinct edges $u v$ and $x y$ as the number of steps that are needed to reach $x y$ from $u v$, where a step moves an edge $w z$ (initially $w z:=u v$ ) to an edge that appears together with $w z$ on the boundary of an internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$. Thus, for example, if $u v$ and $x y$ are incident to the same internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, their distance in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is 1 . The $x y$-parent of the edge $u v$ is the edge $r s$ that appears together with $u v$ on the boundary of an internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ and that is such that the distance between $x y$ and $u v$ in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is 1 plus the distance between $x y$ and $r s$ in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$. The weak dual of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is the graph with a vertex for each internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ and with an edge between two vertices if the corresponding faces of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ share an edge. The weak dual of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is a tree with degree at most 3 . We say that $G$ is a maximal outerpath if its weak dual is a path. An outerpath is a subgraph of a maximal outerpath.

# 3 Induced Subgraphs of Outerplanar Graphs 

In this section, we consider the size of the largest induced subgraph of degree at most $k$ that one is guaranteed to find in an $n$-vertex outerplanar graph. Table 2 shows the coefficients of the linear terms in the size of the induced subgraphs we can find, for various values of $k$.

![table_1](table_1)

Table 2 Results on outerplanar graphs with different values of $k$.
We start with an upper bound, which comes from a family of outerpaths, see Figure 1.

- Theorem 1. For every $n \geq 1$ and for every integer $k \geq 3$, there exists an $n$-vertex outerpath $G$ with the following property. Consider any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. Then $|\mathcal{I}| \leq \frac{k-1}{k} n+2$.

Proof. Let $G$ be the $n$-vertex outerpath depicted in Figure 1 and defined as follows. Let $h=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{k}\right\rfloor$. The graph contains a path $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{h}$, vertices $u_{1}^{i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{i}$, for $i=1, \ldots, h$, and

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1 Illustration for Theorem 1, with $n=18, k=3$, and $h=6$.
edges $u_{j}^{i} u_{j+1}^{i}, v_{i} u_{j}^{i}, v_{i-1} u_{1}^{i}$, and $u_{k-1}^{i} v_{i+1}$, whenever the end-vertices of such edges are in $G$. Additional $n-h \cdot k$ isolated vertices, which do not play any role in the proof, are added to $G$, so that it has $n$ vertices.

Consider any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. We prove that there exists a set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, such that $\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right|=|\mathcal{I}|$, and such that $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ does not contain any of $v_{2}, \ldots, v_{h-1}$. Suppose that $\mathcal{I}$ contains a vertex $v_{i}$, for some $i \in\{2, \ldots, h-1\}$. Then there exists a vertex $w$ among $u_{k-1}^{i-1}, u_{1}^{i}, u_{2}^{i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{i}, u_{1}^{i+1}$ that is not in $\mathcal{I}$, as otherwise $v_{i}$ would have degree $k+1$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Replace $v_{i}$ in $\mathcal{I}$ with $w$. Clearly, the size of $\mathcal{I}$ remains the same. Also, $G[\mathcal{I}]$ still has degree at most $k$. Indeed, the only vertices that have degree larger than $k$ in $G$ are $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{h}$. Also, $w$ is a neighbor of $v_{i}$, which however is not in $\mathcal{I}$ after the replacement, and might be a neighbor of $v_{i-1}$ or $v_{i+1}$. However, $v_{i-1}$ or $v_{i+1}$ are also neighbors of $v_{i}$, hence if they are in $\mathcal{I}$, their degree in $G[\mathcal{I}]$ does not increase. The repetition of this replacement results in the desired set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$.

It remains to observe that $\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right| \leq n-(h-2)=n-\left\lfloor\frac{n}{k}\right\rfloor+2 \leq \frac{k-1}{k} n+2$.
The upper bound of Theorem 1 was proved by considering $n$-vertex outerpaths. For this graph class, the bound is tight, up to additive constants, as proved in the following theorem.

- Theorem 2. For every $n \geq 1$, for every $n$-vertex outerpath $G$, and every integer $k \geq 3$, there exists a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ and $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{k-1}{k} n$.

Proof. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $G$ is a maximal outerpath, as otherwise edges can be added to it so that it becomes maximal, and then a subset $\mathcal{I}$ with the properties required by Theorem 2 in the augmented graph satisfies the same properties in the original graph. Let $e$ be an edge that is incident both to the outer face of the outerplane embedding $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ of $G$ and to an internal face corresponding to an extreme of the weak dual of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$; we refer to $e$ as to the special edge. Also, let $u$ be any of the two end-vertices of $e$, and let $v$ be the other one; we refer to $u$ as to the special vertex. We prove, by induction on $n$, that there exists a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that: (i) $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{k-1}{k} n$; (ii) $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$; and (iii) if the special vertex $u$ is in $\mathcal{I}$, then $u$ has at most $k-1$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}$. This implies the statement of the theorem.

There are two base cases:

- Case 1: $n \leq k$. In this case, we let $\mathcal{I}:=V(G)$. Then $|\mathcal{I}|=n>\frac{k-1}{k} n$. Since there are at most $k$ vertices in $\mathcal{I}$, we have that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k-1$.
- Case 2: $n=k+1$. Let $x$ be any vertex of $G$. We let $\mathcal{I}:=V(G) \backslash\{x\}$. Then $|\mathcal{I}|=k>\frac{(k-1)(k+1)}{k}=\frac{k-1}{k} n$. Since there are at most $k$ vertices in $\mathcal{I}$, we have that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k-1$.

In the inductive case, we have $n \geq k+2$. Our strategy is as follows. We identify an edge $w z$ of $G$ with the following properties. Let $G_{R}$ be the $w z$-split subgraph of $G$ not containing $u v$. Also, let $G_{L}$ be the subgraph of $G$ induced by $V(G) \backslash V\left(G_{R}\right)$. We require that

$G_{L}$ has at least $k$ vertices and that it contains a vertex $h$ such that, by defining $\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{I}_{L} \cup \mathcal{I}_{R}$, where $\mathcal{I}_{L}:=V\left(G_{L}\right) \backslash\{h\}$ and $\mathcal{I}_{R} \subseteq V\left(G_{R}\right)$ is the set obtained by applying induction on $G_{R}$, the conditions of the claim are satisfied. We now make this argument precise.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)
(a)
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
(b)
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
(c)

Figure 2 Illustration for the proof of Theorem 2. Graph $G_{L}$ is striped, vertices and edges in $G_{R}$ are either not shown or colored grey, the active edge is colored red and the active vertex $s$ is colored orange. (a) All the neighbors of the active vertex $s$ are moved into $G_{L}$, which still has at most $k+1$ vertices. (b) All the neighbors of the active vertex $s$ are moved into $G_{L}$, which now has at least $k+2$ vertices. (c) The desired vertex $h$ is set to be $s$, the desired edge $w z$ is set to be $s^{\prime} t^{\prime}, s^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime}$ are moved to $G_{R}, \mathcal{I}_{\mathcal{L}}=V\left(G_{L}\right) \backslash\{h\}$, and induction is applied on $G_{R}$ with $w z$ as a special edge.

In order to find the desired edge $w z$, subgraph $G_{L}$, and vertex $h$, we work iteratively. We initialize $G_{L}$ to consist of the vertices $u$ and $v$ (and of the edge $u v$ ), and $G_{R}$ to $G[V(G) \backslash\{u, v\}]$. Notice that only one of $u$ and $v$ has at least two neighbors in $G_{R}$; such a vertex is called active vertex and $u v$ is the active edge. While $G_{L}$ has at most $k+1$ vertices, let $s$ be the current active vertex and let $s t$ be the current active edge. We move to $G_{L}$ all the neighbors of $s$ that are in $G_{R}$. Let $s^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime}$ be the neighbors of $s$ such that the edge $s^{\prime} t^{\prime}$ exists and its distance from $u v$ in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ is maximum. Now two cases are possible. First, if $G_{L}$ still has at most $k+1$ vertices, as in Figure 2(a), we continue the iteration. Only one of $s^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime}$ has at least two neighbors in $G_{R}$; such a vertex is the new active vertex and $s^{\prime} t^{\prime}$ is the new active edge. Conversely, if $G_{L}$ has at least $k+2$ vertices, as in Figure 2(b), we stop the iteration, we move $s^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime}$ back to $G_{R}$, as in Figure 2(c), we define the desired vertex $h$ to be $s$, the desired edge $w z$ to be $s^{\prime} t^{\prime}$, and the desired graph $G_{L}$ to be the current graph $G_{L}$. We define $\mathcal{I}_{L}=V\left(G_{L}\right) \backslash\{h\}$. We apply induction on $G_{R}$ with $w z$ as a special edge and with the one between $w$ and $z$ that has more than two neighbors in $G_{R}$ as a special vertex. The induction returns us a set $\mathcal{I}_{R} \subseteq V\left(G_{R}\right)$ and we define $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{L} \cup \mathcal{I}_{R}$.

We now show that the set $\mathcal{I}$ satisfies the required properties.

- First, we prove that $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{k-1}{k} n$. By induction, we have $\left|\mathcal{I}_{R}\right| \geq \frac{k-1}{k}\left|V\left(G_{R}\right)\right|$. Also, $\left|V\left(G_{L}\right)\right|$ is at least $k$, given that it is at least $k+2$ before $s^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime}$ are moved back to $G_{R}$. Since $\left|\mathcal{I}_{L}\right|=\left|V\left(G_{L}\right)\right|-1$, we have that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{L}\right| \geq \frac{k-1}{k}\left|V\left(G_{L}\right)\right|$. Hence $|\mathcal{I}|=\left|\mathcal{I}_{L}\right|+\left|\mathcal{I}_{R}\right| \geq$ $\frac{k-1}{k}\left(\left|V\left(G_{L}\right)\right|+\left|V\left(G_{R}\right)\right|\right)=\frac{k-1}{k} n$.
- Second, we prove that, if $u \in \mathcal{I}$, then $u$ has at most $k-1$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}$. Notice that $u$ can have at least $k$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}$ only if it has degree at least $k \geq 3$. This implies that $u$ is selected as the active vertex in the first step of the iteration for the definition of $G_{L}$. If $u$ has degree at least $k+1$, then the iteration defining $G_{L}$ stops at the first step by inserting in $G_{L}$ all the neighbors of $u$, which implies that $h=u$ and that $u$ is not in $\mathcal{I}$. However, if $u$ has degree $k$, then after inserting in $G_{L}$ all the neighbors of $u$, we have that $G_{L}$ has $k+1$ vertices. Now the active vertex becomes one of $u$ 's neighbors, which is then selected as $h$, and hence not inserted in $\mathcal{I}$, given that the second step of the iteration results in $G_{L}$ having at least $k+2$ vertices. Hence, $u$ has $k-1$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}$.
- Finally, we prove that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. Since $w$ and $z$ are the only vertices

of $G_{R}$ with neighbors in $G_{L}$, we have that any vertex in $V\left(G_{R}\right) \backslash\{w, z\}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$, by induction. Next, consider the graph $G_{L}$ and the active edge $s t$ in the step of the iteration defining $G_{L}$ before the last one, i.e., before all the neighbors of $s$ in $G_{R}$ are moved to $G_{L}$ and two of them are moved back to $G_{R}$ since $G_{L}$ has at least $k+2$ vertices. At that point, $G_{L}$ has at most $k+1$ vertices, hence all its vertices other than $s$ and $t$ have degree at most $k$ in $G$ and hence also in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Furthermore, $s$ is not in $\mathcal{I}$, since at the next step of the iteration it is selected as the vertex $h$. Also, $t$ has at most one neighbor not in $G_{L}$, since it is not the active vertex, which bounds its degree in $G[\mathcal{I}]$ to $k$, given that out of its potential $k$ neighbors in $G_{L}$, one of them, namely $s$, is not inserted into $\mathcal{I}$. All the vertices that are inserted into $G_{L}$ at the last step of the iteration, other than $w$ and $z$, have degree 3 in $G$, and hence at most 3 in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. The vertex between $w$ and $z$ that is not selected as the special vertex has two neighbors in $G_{R}$ and at most two neighbors in $G_{L}$, however one of the two neighbors in $G_{L}$ is $h$, hence that vertex has degree at most $3 \leq k$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Finally, the vertex between $w$ and $z$ that is selected as the special vertex has at most $k-1$ neighbors from $G_{R}$ in $\mathcal{I}$ (this is where we use the condition on the degree of the special vertex), and at most two neighbors in $G_{L}$, however one of the two neighbors in $G_{L}$ is $h$, hence that vertex has degree at most $k$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. This concludes the proof of the theorem.

We conclude the section by showing lower bounds for the size of an induced subgraph of degree at most $k$ that one is guaranteed to find in an outerplanar graph. We exhibit three lower bounds, one for $k=3$, one for $k \geq 4$ with $k$ even, and one for $k \geq 5$ with $k$ odd. The first lower bound is tight, because of Theorem 1. Before stating the theorems, we present some tools that we are going to use for their proofs. By the same reasoning used for outerpaths, we can assume that the input is a maximal outerplanar graph $G$. Our first tool is a decomposition lemma, which is stated in the following.

Lemma 3. Let $G$ be an n-vertex maximal outerplanar graph, let $\ell \geq 1$ be an integer, and let $x y$ be an edge incident to the outer face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$. If $n \geq \ell+2$, there exists an edge $u v \in E(G)$ such that a uv-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ satisfies the following properties:

- $H$ has a number $h$ of vertices such that $\ell+2 \leq h \leq 2 \ell+1$; and
- if uv does not coincide with the edge xy, then $H$ does not contain the edge xy.

Proof. The proof is by induction on $n$. In the base case we have $\ell+2 \leq n \leq 2 \ell+1$. Then let $u v$ coincide with $x y$, thus satisfying the second property. Also, $u v$ splits $G$ into two outerplanar graphs, one of which is $G$ and has hence the required number of vertices.

If $n \geq 2 \ell+2$, let $z$ be the vertex such that the cycle $(x, y, z)$ bounds an internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{G}$. Let $G_{1}$ be the $x z$-split subgraph of $G$ that does not contain $y$. Let $G_{2}$ be the $y z$-split subgraph of $G$ that does not contain $x$. We distinguish two cases.

- If both $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$ have less than $2 \ell+2$ vertices, then at least one of them has at least $\ell+2$ vertices, given that $\left|V\left(G_{1}\right)\right|+\left|V\left(G_{2}\right)\right|=n+1 \geq 2 \ell+3$, where the first equality is due to the fact that $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$ share $z$. Then $x z$ or $y z$ is the required edge, depending on whether $G_{1}$ or $G_{2}$ has at least $\ell+2$ vertices, respectively.
- Otherwise, one of $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$, say $G_{1}$, has at least $2 \ell+2$ vertices. See Figure 3. By induction, $G_{1}$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G_{1}$ has a number $h$ of vertices such that $\ell+2 \leq h \leq 2 \ell+1$ and does not contain the edge $x z$. The latter condition implies that $H$ is also one of the two $u v$-split subgraphs of $G$ and that $H$ does not contain the edge $x y$, as required.
This concludes the proof of the lemma.

![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Figure 3 Illustration for the proof of Lemma 3. The case in which $G_{1}$ has at least $2 \ell+2$ vertices. Most internal edges of $G$ are not shown, the interior of $G_{1}$ is striped.

For a subgraph $H$ of $G$, we denote by $\bar{H}$ the subgraph of $G$ induced by $V(G) \backslash V(H)$. Note that $\bar{H}$ is a (not necessarily maximal) outerplanar graph. The basic strategy we use in order to find a large set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ of vertices such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ is the following. By employing Lemma 3, we find an edge $u v$ such that, in a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$, we can select a set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subset V(H)$ of vertices that contains the fraction of the vertices in $V(H)$ we are aiming for ( $\frac{2}{3}$ for $k=3, \frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$ for $k \geq 4$ with $k$ even, and $\frac{2 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3}$ for $k \geq 5$ with $k$ odd), that induces a subgraph of $G$ with degree at most $k$, and that does not contain $u$ and $v$. We also apply induction to find a large set of vertices $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ in $\bar{H}$ such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right]$ has degree at most $k$. Then the set $\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ has the required number of vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. This is formalized in the following lemma.

Lemma 4. Let $k \geq 3$ be an integer and let $0<c<1$ be a real number. Suppose that $G$ contains an edge uv such that one of the two uv-split subgraphs of $G$, say $H$, has a set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ of vertices such that $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ contains neither $u$ nor $v$, such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq c \cdot|V(H)|$, and such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$. Suppose also that $\bar{H}$ has a set $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ of vertices such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right| \geq c \cdot|V(\bar{H})|$ and such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right]$ has degree at most $k$.

Then the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $c \cdot n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$.
Proof. That $\mathcal{I}$ contains at least $c \cdot n$ vertices follows by the assumption on the cardinalities of $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$, and by $|V(H)|+|V(\bar{H})|=n$. That $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ follows by the assumption on the degrees of $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ and $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right]$, and by the fact that $u$ and $v$, which do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, are the only vertices of $H$ with neighbors in $\bar{H}$.

We are now ready to present our theorems. We start with the one for induced subgraphs of degree at most 3 .

Theorem 5. For every $n \geq 1$, for every $n$-vertex outerplanar graph $G$, there exists a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 and $[\mathcal{I}] \geq \frac{2}{3} n$.

Proof. Let $G$ be an $n$-vertex maximal outerplanar graph. The proof is by induction on $n$. In the base case we have $n \leq 11$. An easy edge-counting argument proves that we can find a set $\mathcal{I}$ with $n$ vertices (if $1 \leq n \leq 4$ ), with $n-1$ vertices (if $5 \leq n \leq 6$ ), with $n-2$ vertices (if $7 \leq n \leq 8$ ), or with $n-3$ vertices (if $9 \leq n \leq 10$ ) such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 . In all four cases the ratio $\frac{|\mathcal{I}|}{n}$ is larger than or equal to $\frac{2}{3}$. The edge-counting argument is as follows. Observe that $\mathcal{O}_{G}$ has $n-3$ internal edges and that, for any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$, a vertex with degree at least 4 in $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has at least two incident edges that are internal in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$. Hence, we can initialize $\mathcal{I}=V(G)$ and then repeatedly remove from $\mathcal{I}$ a vertex with degree at least 4 in $G[\mathcal{I}]$, while such a vertex exists. If $n \leq 4$, then $G$ has at most 1 edge that is internal in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, hence no vertex is removed from $\mathcal{I}$. If $5 \leq n \leq 6$, then $G$ has up to 3 edges that are internal in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, hence up to 1 vertex is removed from $\mathcal{I}$. If $7 \leq n \leq 8$, then $G$ has up to 5 edges that are internal in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, hence up to 2 vertices are removed from $\mathcal{I}$. Finally, if $9 \leq n \leq 10$, then $G$ has up to 7 edges that are internal in $\mathcal{O}_{G}$, hence up to 3 vertices are removed from $\mathcal{I}$.

If $n=11$, the above argument requires some amendment, since $G$ has 8 internal edges, hence charging pairs of internal edges to removed degree- 4 vertices only upper bounds the number of removed vertices by 4 , while we need to show that the number of removed vertices is at most 3 in order to get our desired $\frac{2}{3}$ ratio. The key observation is that, after initializing $\mathcal{I}=V(G)$ and removing from $\mathcal{I}$ the first vertex $v$ with degree at least 4 in $G$, the number of internal edges in $G[\mathcal{I}]$ decreases at least by three. This is obvious if the degree of $v$ in $G$ is at least 5 . If the degree of $v$ in $G$ is 4 , let $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ be the internal edges of $G$ incident to $v$, and let $v_{0}, v_{1}, v_{2}$, and $v_{3}$ be the neighbors of $v$, where $e_{1}=v v_{1}$ and $e_{2}=v v_{2}$ lie inside the cycle $\left(v, v_{0}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3}\right)$ of $G$. Then one of the edges of the path $\left(v_{0}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3}\right)$ is an internal edge $e$ of $G$, as otherwise $G$ would not be a maximal outerplanar graph or it would contain 5 vertices. Hence, the removal of $v$ from $\mathcal{I}$ not only removes $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ from $G[\mathcal{I}]$, but also makes $e$ an external edge of $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Since the number of internal edges of $G[\mathcal{I}]$ after the removal of $v$ is at most 5 , at most 2 more degree- 4 vertices are then removed from $G[\mathcal{I}]$.

Suppose now that $n \geq 12$. As argued before the theorem, it suffices to discuss the case in which $G$ is a maximal outerplanar graph. We define a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ with a suitable size, then we select a large set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subseteq V(H)$ of vertices, with $u, v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . Applying induction on $\bar{H}$ to get a set $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ and then applying Lemma 4 allows us to define the desired set $\mathcal{I}$. We distinguish 16 cases, labelled from 6 to 21 , according to the size of a $u v$-split subgraph that we can find in $G$ - we need to consider every size in this range. Eventually, we will use Lemma 3 with $\ell=10$, in order to find a $u v$-split subgraph with a number of vertices between 12 and 21, however for our arguments we need to consider $u v$-split subgraphs of smaller sizes, as well. In the following, whenever we consider a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$, we denote by $w$ the vertex such that the cycle $(u, v, w)$ bounds an internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{H}$ and by $h$ the number of vertices of $H$. Also, we denote by $H_{1}$ the $u w$-split subgraph of $G$ not containing $v$ and by $H_{2}$ the $v w$-split subgraph of $G$ not containing $u$. We let $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ be the number of vertices of $H_{1}$ and $H_{2}$, respectively, where $h_{1} \geq 2, h_{2} \geq 2$, and $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$, given that $w$ belongs both to $H_{1}$ and to $H_{2}$. Finally, we denote by $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}} \subseteq V(\bar{H})$ a set such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right]$ has degree at most 3 and $\left|\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}\right| \geq \frac{2}{3}|V(\bar{H})|$. This set exists by induction.

Case 6: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has 6 vertices. We define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{4}{6}=\frac{2}{3}$. Also, $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ contains 4 vertices, hence $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . By Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired. We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6 vertices.

Case 7: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=7$ vertices. Then we have $h_{1} \geq 3$, as otherwise $H_{2}$ would have 6 vertices. Symmetrically, $h_{2} \geq 3$. If there exists a vertex in $V(H) \backslash\{w\}$ that is not adjacent to $w$, then we define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$. Then $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{8}{7}>\frac{2}{3}$. Also, $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 , given that $w$ is adjacent to at most 3 vertices in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by assumption, given that each vertex in $V\left(H_{1}\right) \backslash\{u, w\}$ is not adjacent to at least 1 vertex of $H_{2}$, and given that each vertex in $V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{v, w\}$ is not adjacent to at least 1 vertex of $H_{1}$. By Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{4}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We henceforth assume that, if $G$ has an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has 7 vertices, then the degree of $w$ in $H$ is 6 . This implies that $H$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $u$, a 5 -over-7 set with $v$, and a 6 -over-7 set with $u$ and $v$. A 5 -over-7 set with $u$ is a set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ of vertices such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=5$, such that $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 , and such that the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 1 . Indeed, the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{v, w\}$ satisfies these properties, see Figure 4(a). The definition of a

5-over-7 set with $v$ is analogous, with $v$ in place of $u$ and vice versa, and is realized by the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, w\}$, see Figure 4(b). A 6 -over-7 set with $u$ and $v$ is a set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ of vertices such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=6$, such that $u, v \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 , and such that the degree of $u$ and $v$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 2 . Indeed, the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{w\}$ satisfies these properties, see Figure 4(c). Although we cannot use such sets to exclude the existence of a $u v$-split subgraph with 7 vertices, since they contain $u$ or $v$, we will use them in later cases.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 4 A $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with 7 vertices in which the vertex $w$ has degree 6. (a) A 5 -over-7 set with $u$. (b) A 5 -over-7 set with $v$. (c) A 6 -over-7 set with $u$ and $v$. Vertices in the sets have a circular contour, while vertices not in the sets have a cross.

Case 8: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=8$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 2 and the other one is 7 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 4 and the other one is 5 .

- Suppose that $h_{1}=2$ and $h_{2}=7$, the case in which $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=2$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$, and a 6 -over-7 set with $w$ and $v$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{u w}$. This implies that $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$ and a 6 -over-8 set with $v$. The former is a set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ of vertices such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=6$, such that $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 , and such that the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 2 . Indeed, the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\{u\}$ satisfies these properties, see Figure 5(a). The definition of a 6 -over-8 set with $v$ is analogous, with $v$ in place of $u$ and vice versa, and is realized by the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{u w}$, see Figure 5(b). We also have that $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$-deg-1 or a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1. The former is a 6 -over-8 set with $u$ such that the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 1 . The latter is a 6 -over-8 set with $v$ such that the degree of $v$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 1 . Indeed, with the current assumption $h_{1}=2$ and $h_{2}=7$, we have that $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$-deg-1, while if $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=2$, then $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1. Although we cannot use such sets to exclude the existence of a $u v$-split subgraph with 8 vertices, given that they contain $u$ or $v$, we will use them in later cases.

Figure 5 A $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with 8 vertices with $h_{1}=2$ and $h_{2}=7$. (a) A 6 -over-8 set with $u$. (b) A 6 -over-8 set with $v$.

- Suppose that $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=5$, the case in which $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=4$ is symmetric. If $w$ has at most 3 neighbors among the vertices in $V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$, then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$. Then $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{6}{8}>\frac{2}{3}$. Also, $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . Indeed, consider any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$. If $z=w$, then $z$ is adjacent to at most 3 vertices in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by assumption. If $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ and $z \neq w$ then $z$ is not adjacent to the 2 vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$ and is not adjacent to $z$ itself. Since $u$ and $v$ are not in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$,

we have that $z$ has at most 3 neighbors in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. The argument for the case in which $z \in V\left(H_{1}\right)$ and $z \neq w$ is analogous.
