Figure 6 A $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with 8 vertices with $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=5$. (a) A 6 -over-8 set with $u$. (b) A 6 -over-8 set with $v$.

We henceforth assume that, if $G$ has an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has 8 vertices and if the $u w$-split subgraph $H_{1}$ has 4 or 5 vertices, then $w$ has degree at least 6 in $H$. This again implies that $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$ and a 6 -over-8 set with $v$. Indeed, the former is realized by the set $V(H) \backslash\{v, w\}$, see Figure 6(a), and the latter is realized by the set $V(H) \backslash\{u, w\}$, see Figure 6(b). Also, $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$-deg-1 or a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1. Indeed, with the current assumption $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=5$, we have that $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1, see again Figure 6(b), while if $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=4$ then $H$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $u$-deg-1.

Case 9: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=9$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 2 and the other one is 8 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 3 and the other one is 7 , or both $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ are 5 .

- Suppose that $h_{1}=2$ and $h_{2}=8$, the case in which $h_{1}=8$ and $h_{2}=2$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 and $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{6}{9}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose next that $h_{1}=3$ and $h_{2}=7$, the case in which $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=3$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. We define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\{t\}$, where $t$ is the vertex of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{6}{9}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 5 -over-7 set with $w$ and since $w$ is the only vertex of $H_{2}$ adjacent to $t$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose finally that $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=5$. We define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v, w\}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{6}{9}=\frac{2}{3}$. Also, each vertex $z$ in $\mathcal{I}_{H} \cap V\left(H_{1}\right)$ is adjacent to at most 2 vertices in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, namely those in $\mathcal{I}_{H} \cap V\left(H_{1}\right)$ different from $z$ itself, given that $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ adjacent to vertices of $H_{2}$. Analogously, each vertex in $\mathcal{I}_{H} \cap V\left(H_{2}\right)$ is adjacent to at most 2 vertices in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$. It follows that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 2 . By Lemma 4, the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 9 vertices.
Case 10: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=10$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6 or 9 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 3 and the other one is 8 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 4 and the other one is 7 .

- Suppose that $h_{1}=3$ and $h_{2}=8$, the case in which $h_{1}=8$ and $h_{2}=3$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\{t\}$, where $t$ is the vertex of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{r}{10}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$ and since $w$ is the only vertex of $H_{2}$ adjacent to $t$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose that $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=7$, the case in which $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=4$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=$ $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$, where $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$ are the vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{r}{10}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 5 -over-7 set with $w$ and since $w$ is the only vertex of $H_{2}$ adjacent to $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 10 vertices.
Case 11: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=11$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6,9 , or 10 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 4 and the other one is 8 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 5 and the other one is 7 .
- Suppose that $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=8$, the case in which $h_{1}=8$ and $h_{2}=4$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$, and a 6 -over-8 set with $v$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v}$. Also by assumption, we have that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is actually a 6 -over-8 set with $w$-deg-1 or that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v}$ is actually a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1.
Suppose first that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$-deg-1. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=$ $I_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$, where $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$ are the vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{8}{11}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$-deg-1 and since $w$ is the only vertex of $H_{2}$ adjacent to $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
Suppose next that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $v$-deg-1. If $w$ has at most one neighbor among $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$, then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=I_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$ and conclude the induction as above, hence we can assume that $w$ is adjacent to both $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$. This implies that $u$ is a neighbor of at most one of $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$. It follows that $H$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $u$ and a 8 -over-11 set with $v$. The former is a set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ of vertices such that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=8$, such that $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 , and such that the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 1 . Indeed, the set $\left(\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}\right) \cup\left\{u, t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$ satisfies these properties. The definition of a 8 -over-11 set with $v$ is analogous, with $v$ in place of $u$ and vice versa, and is realized by the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$.

- Suppose that $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=7$, the case in which $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=5$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$, and a 5 -over-7 set with $v$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v}$. Suppose first that $w$ is adjacent to at most 2 out of the 3 vertices $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right\}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{8}{11}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 5 -over-7 set with $w$ and since $w$ is the only vertex of $H_{2}$ adjacent to $t_{1}, t_{2}$ or $t_{3}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$, by the assumption that it is

not adjacent to all of $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired. Suppose next that $w$ is adjacent to all of $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$. This implies that $u$ is a neighbor of at most one of $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$. It follows that $H$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $u$ and a 8 -over-11 set with $v$. The former is realized by the set $\left(\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}\right) \cup\left\{u, t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right\}$ and the latter by the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{v} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right\}$.

Although we cannot exclude the existence of a $u v$-split subgraph with 11 vertices, we will use the existence of a 8 -over-11 set with $u$ and of a 8 -over-11 set with $v$ in later cases.

Case 12: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=12$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has 6,9 , or 10 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 2 and the other one is 11 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 5 and the other one is 8 .

- Suppose that $h_{1}=2$ and $h_{2}=11$, the case in which $h_{1}=11$ and $h_{2}=2$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{8}{12}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose that $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=8$, the case in which $h_{1}=8$ and $h_{2}=5$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}$ be the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right\}$, where $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ are the vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}\right|=5$, hence $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{8}{12}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, each of $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ has degree at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$ and then also $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . Since $v$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ with neighbors in $H_{1}$, it follows that every vertex in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}$ has degree at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 12 vertices.

Case 13: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=13$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has $6,9,10$, or 12 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 3 and the other one is 11 , or $h_{1}=h_{2}=7$.

- Suppose that $h_{1}=3$ and $h_{2}=11$, the case in which $h_{1}=11$ and $h_{2}=3$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup$ $\left\{t_{1}\right\}$, where $t_{1}$ is the vertex of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{u}{13}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has at most one neighbor in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$, hence it has degree at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose that $h_{1}=h_{2}=7$. By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, and $H_{2}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{9}{13}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ and $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ are 5 -over-7 sets with $w$, since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, and since $v$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ with neighbors in $H_{1}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in each of $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 2 in

$G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 13 vertices.

Case 14: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=14$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has $6,9,10,12$, or 13 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 4 and the other one is 11 , or one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 7 and the other one is 8 .

- Suppose that $h_{1}=4$ and $h_{2}=11$, the case in which $h_{1}=11$ and $h_{2}=4$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=$ $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}\right\}$, where $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$ are the vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{10}{14}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has at most one neighbor in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$, hence it has degree at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose that $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=8$, the other case is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, and $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{10}{14}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, and since $v$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ with neighbors in $H_{1}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 14 vertices.

Case 15: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=15$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has $6,9,10,12,13$, or 14 vertices, we have that either one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 5 and the other one is 11 , or $h_{1}=h_{2}=8$.

- Suppose that $h_{1}=5$ and $h_{2}=11$, the case in which $h_{1}=11$ and $h_{2}=5$ is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=$ $\left.\left(\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}\right) \cup\left\{t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right\}\right.$, where $t_{1}, t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ are the vertices of $H_{1}$ different from $u$ and $w$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{10}{15}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 . Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.
- Suppose that $h_{1}=h_{2}=8$. By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, and $H_{2}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}$ be the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}$ and let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}$ be the set $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{10}{15}=\frac{2}{3}$. Since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, the degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ of each vertex in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}$ is the same as its degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}\right]$, hence at most 3 . Analogously, the degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ of each vertex in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}$ is at most 3 . Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 15 vertices.

Case 16: We observe that, with the current assumptions, $G$ does not contain any edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=16$ vertices. Indeed, since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$, if $H$ had $h=16$ vertices, one of $H_{1}$ and $H_{2}$ would contain $6,9,10,12,13,14$, or 15 vertices, which we already excluded.

Case 17: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=17$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has $9,10,12,13,14,15$, or 16 vertices, we have that one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 7 and the other one is 11 . Suppose that $h_{1}=7$ and $h_{2}=11$, as the other case is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, and $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{12}{17}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is a 5 -over-7 set with $w$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, and since $v$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ with neighbors in $H_{1}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 1 in each of $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired. We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 17 vertices.

Case 18: Suppose that $G$ contains an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=18$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has $10,12,13,14,15,16$, or 17 vertices, we have that one of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ is 8 and the other one is 11 . Suppose that $h_{1}=8$ and $h_{2}=11$, as the other case is symmetric. By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ and $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{12}{18}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is a 6 -over-8 set with $w$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, since $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ with neighbors in $H_{2}$, and since $v$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ with neighbors in $H_{1}$, we have that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most 3 ; in particular, $w$ has degree at most 2 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and at most 1 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most 3 in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. Since $u$ and $v$ do not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired. We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has 18 vertices.

Case 19: We observe that, with the current assumptions, $G$ does not contain any edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=19$ vertices. Indeed, since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$, if $H$ had $h=19$ vertices, one of $H_{1}$ and $H_{2}$ would contain $9,10,12,13,14,15,16,17$, or 18 vertices, which we already excluded.

Case 20: We observe that, with the current assumptions, $G$ does not contain any edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ has $h=20$ vertices. Indeed, since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$, if $H$ had $h=20$ vertices, one of $H_{1}$ and $H_{2}$ would contain $10,12,13,14,15,16,17,18$, or 19 vertices, which we already excluded.

Case 21: By Lemma 3, applied with $\ell=10$, since $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has a number of vertices between 12 and 20 , we have that $G$ has an edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph has $h=21$ vertices. Since $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$ and $G$ has no edge $x y$ such that an $x y$-split subgraph of $G$ has a number of vertices between 12 and 20 , we have that $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ are both 11 . By assumption, $H_{1}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, and $H_{2}$ admits a 8 -over-11 set with $w$, say $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Then we can define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$. Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| /|V(H)|=\frac{15}{21}>\frac{2}{3}$. Since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ and $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ are 8 -over-11 sets with $w$, it follows that the degree of $w$ in each of $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$ is at most 1 , hence its degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 2 . Since the degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ of every vertex in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{i}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}$ is the same as its degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{i}}^{w}\right]$, for $i=1,2$, it follows that the degree of $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most 3 . Since $u$ and $v$ do not

belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}$, by Lemma 4 , the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{2}{3} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 , as desired.

We conclude with the theorem for induced subgraphs with degree at most $k \geq 4$.
Theorem 6. For every $n \geq 1$, for every $n$-vertex outerplanar graph $G$, and for every integer $k \geq 4$, there exists a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ and $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5} n$ (if $k$ is even) or $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{3 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3} n$ (if $k$ is odd).

Proof. Let $G$ be an $n$-vertex maximal outerplanar graph and let $k$ be an integer greater than or equal to 4 . We assume first that $k$ is even, we will discuss later the case in which $k$ is odd.

The proof is by induction on $n$. In the base case we have $n \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$. If $n \leq k+1$, then we can set $\mathcal{I}:=V(G)$ and obviously $G[\mathcal{I}]=G$ has degree at most $k$ and $|\mathcal{I}|>\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5} n$. If $k+2 \leq n \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$, then the proof is similar to the one for the base case of Theorem 5. Namely, we can initialize $\mathcal{I}=V(G)$ and then repeatedly remove from $\mathcal{I}$ a vertex with degree at least $k+1$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$, while such a vertex exists. The removal of the first vertex from $\mathcal{I}$ removes at least $k$ internal edges from $G[\mathcal{I}]$ (by the same arguments presented for the case $n=11$ in the proof of Theorem 5), while the removal of the second vertex from $\mathcal{I}$ removes at least $k-1$ internal edges from $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Since $G$ has $n-3 \leq \frac{3 k}{2}$ internal edges, and since $2 k-1>\frac{3 k}{2}$ for $k>2$, it follows that a single vertex is removed from $\mathcal{I}$. Hence, $|\mathcal{I}|=n-1 \geq \frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5} n$, where the last inequality is equivalent to $n \geq \frac{2 k+5}{4}$, which holds true by the assumption $n \geq k+2$ and since $k+2 \geq \frac{2 k+5}{4}$ for $k \geq 0$.

In the inductive case, we have $n \geq \frac{3 k}{2}+4$. As in Theorem 5, the general strategy consists of defining a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ with a suitable size and of then selecting a large set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subseteq V(H)$ of vertices, with $u, v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$. Applying induction on $\bar{H}$ to get a set $\mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ and then applying Lemma 4 allows us to obtain the desired set $\mathcal{I}$.

Let $H$ be a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ with $h$ vertices. A set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subseteq V(H)$ is called good for $H$ if it contains neither $u$ nor $v$, if $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, and if:
$\Rightarrow k+3 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ and $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-2$; or
$\Rightarrow \frac{3 k}{2}+4 \leq h \leq 2 k+4$ and $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-3$; or
$\Rightarrow 2 k+5 \leq h \leq 3 k+5$ and $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-4$.
Also, a set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subseteq V(H)$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ if $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-2$, if $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, if $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, and if the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most $h-k-3$. An $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$ is defined analogously, with $v$ in place of $u$ and vice versa. Finally, a set $\mathcal{I}_{H} \subseteq V(H)$ is an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$ if $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-1$, if $u, v \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$, if $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, and if the degree of $u$ and $v$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most $h-k-2$.

We are going to prove the following three statements.
$\Rightarrow$ (S1) If $h=k+3$, then there exists a good set for $H$.
$\Rightarrow$ (S2) Suppose that:
$\Rightarrow k+4 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$
$\Rightarrow G$ has no $s t$-split subgraph with $k+3$ vertices; and
$\Rightarrow$ for every integer $j$ with $k+4 \leq j \leq h-1$ and for every $s t$-split subgraph $J$ of $G$ with $j$ vertices, we have that $J$ has a $(j-2)$-over- $j$ set with $s$, a $(j-2)$-over- $j$ set with $t$, and a $(j-1)$-over- $j$ set with $s$ and $t$.
Then there exists a good set for $H$, or there exist an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$, an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$, and an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$.
$\Rightarrow$ (S3) Suppose that:
$\Rightarrow \frac{3 k}{2}+4 \leq h \leq 3 k+5$

- $G$ has no $s t$-split subgraph with $k+3$ vertices;
- for every integer $j$ with $k+4 \leq j \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ and for every $s t$-split subgraph $J$ of $G$ with $j$ vertices, we have that $J$ has a $(j-2)$-over- $j$ set with $s$, a $(j-2)$-over- $j$ set with $t$, and a $(j-1)$-over- $j$ set with $s$ and $t$; and
- for every integer $j$ with $\frac{3 k}{2}+4 \leq j \leq h-1, G$ has no $s t$-split subgraph with $j$ vertices. Then there exists a good set for $H$.

Before proving the statements we prove that they imply the theorem (if $k$ is even).
First, suppose that $G$ has a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with $k+3$ vertices. By statement (S1), there exists a good set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ for $H$; by definition, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=k+1$. Hence, $\frac{\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|}{\left|V(H)\right|}=\frac{k+1}{k+3}>\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5}$, where the last inequality is true for every value of $k$. Also, $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ contains $k+1$ vertices, hence $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$. By Lemma 4, the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$, as desired. We henceforth assume that $G$ has no edge $u v$ such that a $u v$-split subgraph of $G$ has $k+3$ vertices.

Second, suppose that $G$ has a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with $h$ vertices, where $k+4 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$, such that there exists no $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$, or there exists no $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$, or there exists no $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$. Among all such subgraphs, choose one such that $h$ is minimum. Then the assumptions of statement (S2) are met, thus there exists a good set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ for $H$. Hence, $\frac{\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|}{\left|V(H)\right|}=\frac{h-2}{h}>\frac{k+1}{k+3}>\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5}$, where the first inequality comes from $h \geq k+4$. Also, $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$ since $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ is a good set. By Lemma 4, the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$, as desired. We henceforth assume that for every integer $h$ with $k+4 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ and for every $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ with $h$ vertices, $H$ has an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$, an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $t$, and an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$.

Third, setting $\ell=\frac{3 k}{2}+2$ and observing that $n \geq \ell+2$ by the hypothesis of the inductive case, Lemma 3 ensures that $G$ contains a $u v$-split subgraph $H$ with a number $h$ of vertices between $\frac{3 k}{2}+4$ and $3 k+5$. Among all such subgraphs, choose one such that $h$ is minimum. Then the assumptions of statement (S3) are met, thus there exists a good set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ for $H$. If $\frac{3 k}{2}+4 \leq h \leq 2 k+4$, then $\frac{\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|}{\left|V(H)\right|}=\frac{h-3}{h} \geq \frac{(3 k / 2)+1}{(3 k / 2)+4}>\frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$, where the last inequality is true for $k \geq 0$, while if $2 k+5 \leq h \leq 3 k+5$, then $\frac{\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|}{\left|V(H)\right|}=\frac{h-4}{h} \geq \frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$. Also, $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$ since $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ is a good set. By Lemma 4, the set $\mathcal{I}:=\mathcal{I}_{H} \cup \mathcal{I}_{\bar{H}}$ contains at least $\frac{3 k+1}{2 k+5} n$ vertices and $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$, as desired. This completes the induction.

It remains to prove the three statements. We denote by $w$ the vertex such that the cycle $(u, v, w)$ bounds an internal face of $\mathcal{O}_{H}$, by $H_{1}$ the $u w$-split subgraph of $G$ not containing $v$, and by $H_{2}$ the $v w$-split subgraph of $G$ not containing $u$. We let $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ be the number of vertices of $H_{1}$ and $H_{2}$, respectively, where $h_{1} \geq 2, h_{2} \geq 2$, and $h_{1}+h_{2}=h+1$.

Statement (S1). We define $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$. Obviously, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=k+1=h-2$ and $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, given that $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ contains $k+1$ vertices, hence $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ is a good set. Statement (S2). We distinguish three cases.

- In the first case, vertex $w$ has at least $k+1$ neighbors in $V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$. We prove that the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}:=V(H) \backslash\{w, v\}$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$. The proof exploits the fact that any two vertices of $H$ share at most two neighbors in $H$ (as otherwise such two vertices and their common neighbors would induce $K_{2,3}$, whereas $H$ is an outerplanar graph). First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right|=h-2$, as desired. Second, $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$ and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \neq u$ of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$. Namely, $w$ has at least $k+2$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$ (at least $k+1$ in $V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$, by hypothesis, plus $u$ ). One of such neighbors might be $z$ and at most 2 of them might be shared with $z$. Hence, out of the $h-3$ vertices of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$ different from $z$, at least $(k-1)$ are different from $z$ and

are not neighbors of $z$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$, which proves that the degree of $z$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$ is at most $(h-3)-(k-1)$. Since $h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$, we have $(h-3)-(k-1) \leq \frac{k}{2}+1 \leq k$, where the last inequality is equivalent to $k \geq 2$. Finally, we prove that $u$ has degree at most $h-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$. Note that $u$ and $w$ share $v$ as a neighbor in $H$, hence out of the at least $k+2$ neighbors of $w$ in $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$, at most one of them is a neighbor of $u$. Hence, out of the $h-3$ vertices of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}$ different from $u$, at least $k$ are different from $u$ and are not neighbors of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$, which proves that the degree of $u$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$ is at most $(h-3)-k$. Observe that $h-k-3 \leq k$ since $h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ and $k \geq 0$.
The proof that the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, w\}$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$ is symmetric. The proof that the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n v}:=V(H) \backslash\{w\}$ is an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$ is also analogous; in particular, now the degree of any vertex $z \notin\{u, v\}$ of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n v}$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n v}\right]$ might be as large as $(h-2)-(k-1)=h-k-1$, that is, one more than in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$. Since $h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$, we have $h-k-1 \leq \frac{k}{2}+2 \leq k$, where the last inequality is equivalent to $k \geq 4$. Also, the degree of $u$ in $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n v}$ is one more than in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$, since $u$ is a neighbor of $v$, hence it is at most $(h-2)-k$, as required.

- In the second case, vertex $w$ has at most $k$ neighbors in $V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}, h_{1} \leq k+2$, and $h_{2} \leq k+2$. We prove that the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$ is a good set for $H$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-2$, as desired. Second, $u, v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. If $z=w$, this comes from the assumption that $w$ has at most $k$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$. If $z \neq w$ and $z \in V\left(H_{1}\right)$ (the case in which $z \neq w$ and $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ is symmetric), then the neighbors of $z$ are all in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$. Since $h_{1} \leq k+2$ and since $u$ and $z$ are not neighbors of $z$, it follows that the degree of $z$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most $k$, as required.
- In the third case, vertex $w$ has at most $k$ neighbors in $V(H) \backslash\{u, v\}$, and $h_{1} \geq k+3$ or $h_{2} \geq k+3$. By the assumptions of statement (S2), $h_{1} \neq k+3$ and $h_{2} \neq k+3$, hence $h_{1} \geq k+4$ or $h_{2} \geq k+4$. Since $2 k+8>\frac{3}{2} k+3$, for every $k \geq 0$, it follows that $h_{1} \geq k+4$ and $h_{2} \geq k+4$ do not both hold. Assume, w.l.o.g., that $h_{1} \geq k+4$, as the case $h_{2} \geq k+4$ can be discussed symmetrically. Since $2 k+4>\frac{3}{2} k+3$, for every $k \geq 0$, we have $h_{2} \leq k-1$.
We prove that $H$ has an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$. By the assumptions of statement (S2) and since $k+4 \leq h_{1} \leq h-1$, we have that $H_{1}$ admits an $\left(h_{1}-1\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $u$ and $w$, which we denote by $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w} \cup\left(V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{v\}\right)$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right|=h-2$, given that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ contains all the vertices of $H_{1}$, except for one, and given that $V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{v\}$ contains all the vertices of $H_{2}$, except for $v$. Second, $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$, given that $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$, and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \neq u$ of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$. If $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$. Also, if $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$ since $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ contains at most $k-1$ vertices and $v$ is not in $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$. If $z=w$, then $z$ has at most $h_{1}-k-2$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ and at most $h_{2}-2$ neighbors in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ (that is, all the vertices of $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ except for $v$ and $w$ itself). Thus, its degree is at most $h_{1}-k-2+h_{2}-2=h-k-3 \leq\left(\frac{3 k}{2}+3\right)-k-3=\frac{k}{2}<k$. Finally, we prove that $u$ has degree at most $h-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$. We have that all the neighbors of $u$ are in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$, given that $w$ and $v$ are the only vertices of $H_{2}$ that are neighbors of $u$, that $w$ also belongs to $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$, and that $v$ does not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$. It follows that $u$ has degree at most $h_{1}-k-2 \leq h-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{n}\right]$, as required.
We next prove that $H$ has an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ be an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$ for $H_{1}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup V\left(H_{2}\right)$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$.

First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right|=h-2$, given that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ contains all the vertices of $H_{1}$, except for two. Second, $u \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$, and $v \in \mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \neq v$ of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right]$. If $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$. Also, if $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k-2$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right]$ since $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ contains at most $k-1$ vertices. If $z=w$, then $z$ has at most $h_{1}-k-3$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ and at most $h_{2}-1$ neighbors in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ (that is, all the vertices of $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ except for $w$ itself). Thus, its degree is at most $h_{1}-k-3+h_{2}-1=h-k-3 \leq\left(\frac{3 k}{2}+3\right)-k-3=\frac{k}{2}<k$. Finally, we prove that $v$ has degree at most $h-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right]$. All the neighbors of $v$ are in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$, given that $u$ and $w$ are the only vertices of $H_{1}$ that are neighbors of $v$, given that $w$ also belongs to $H_{2}$, and given that $u$ does not belong to $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}$. It follows that $v$ has degree at most $h_{2}-1=h-h_{1} \leq h-k-4$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}\right]$, as required.
We now prove that $H$ has an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ be an $\left(h_{1}-1\right)$ -over- $h_{1}$ set with $u$ and $w$ for $H_{1}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w} \cup V\left(H_{2}\right)$ is an $(h-1)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ and $v$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}\right|=h-1$, given that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ contains all the vertices of $H_{1}$, except for one. Second, $u \in \mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}$ and $v \in \mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \neq u, v$ of $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}\right]$. The arguments for the case in which $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ (in which $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ ) with $z \neq w$ are the same as for the proof that $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u}$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $u$ (that $\mathcal{I}_{H}^{v}$ is an $(h-2)$-over- $h$ set with $v$, respectively). If $z=w$, then $z$ has at most $h_{1}-k-2$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$ and at most $h_{2}-1$ neighbors in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ (that is, all the vertices of $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ except for $w$ itself). Thus, its degree is at most $h_{1}-k-2+h_{2}-1=h-k-2 \leq\left(\frac{3 k}{2}+3\right)-k-2=\frac{k}{2}+1<k$, where the last inequality holds true since $k \geq 4$. Finally, we prove that $u$ and $v$ have degree at most $h-k-2$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}\right]$. We have that all the neighbors of $u$ are in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u w}$, except for $v$. It follows that $u$ has degree at most $\left(h_{1}-k-2\right)+1 \leq h-k-2$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}\right]$, as required. Also, all the neighbors of $v$ are in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$, except for $u$. It follows that $v$ has degree at most $\left(h_{2}-1\right)+1=\left(h-h_{1}\right)+1 \leq h-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{u v}\right]$, as required.
Statement (S3). We distinguish three cases.

- In the first case, we have $h_{1} \leq k+2$ and $h_{2} \leq k+2$. We prove that the set $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=V(H) \backslash\{u, w, v\}$ is a good set for $H$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-3$, which is the desired number of vertices, given that $h \geq k+4$, by the assumptions of statement (S3). Second, $u, v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. If $z \in V\left(H_{1}\right)$ (the case in which $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ is symmetric), then the neighbors of $z$ are all in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$. Since $h_{1} \leq k+2$ and since $u, w$, and $z$ are either not in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ or are not neighbors of $z$, it follows that the degree of $z$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most $k-1$, as required.
- In the second case, we have that $h \leq 2 k+4, \max \left\{h_{1}, h_{2}\right\}>k+2$, and $\min \left\{h_{1}, h_{2}\right\} \leq$ $k+2$. Assume that $h_{1}>k+2$ and that $h_{2} \leq k+2$, as the other case is analogous. By the assumptions of statement (S3), we have $k+4 \leq h_{1} \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ be an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$ for $H_{1}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup\left(V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{v\}\right)$ is a good set for $H$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-3$, which is equal to the desired number of vertices, given that $h \geq \frac{3 k}{2}+4$, by the assumptions of statement (S3). Second, $u \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$, and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. If $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}^{w}\right]$. Also, if $z \in V\left(H_{2}\right)$ with $z \neq w$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{2}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ since $V\left(H_{2}\right)$ contains at

most $k+2$ vertices, $v$ is not in $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ and $z$ is not a neighbor of itself. Finally, $w$ has at most $h_{1}-k-3$ neighbors in $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ and at most $h_{2}-2$ neighbors in $V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{v\}$, hence its degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ is at most $h_{1}-k-3+h_{2}-2=h-k-4 \leq k$, where the last inequality uses $h \leq 2 k+4$.

- In the third case, we have that $h \geq 2 k+5, \max \left\{h_{1}, h_{2}\right\}>k+2$, and $\min \left\{h_{1}, h_{2}\right\} \leq k+2$. Assume that $h_{1}>k+2$ and that $h_{2} \leq k+2$, as the other case is analogous. By the assumptions of statement (S3), we have $k+4 \leq h_{1} \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ be an ( $h_{1}-2$ )-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$ for $H_{1}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\left(\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \backslash\{w\}\right) \cup\left(V\left(H_{2}\right) \backslash\{w, v\}\right)$ is a good set for $H$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-4$, which is equal to the desired number of vertices, given that $h \geq 2 k+5$, by the assumptions of statement (S3). Second, $u \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{u}$ is an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$, and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, by construction. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. If $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{1}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}\right]$.
- In the fourth case, we have $\min \left\{h_{1}, h_{2}\right\}>k+2$. By the assumptions statement (S3), we have $k+4 \leq h_{1} \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ and $k+4 \leq h_{2} \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$. Let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ be an $\left(h_{1}-2\right)$-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$ for $H_{1}$ and let $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ be an $\left(h_{2}-2\right)$-over- $h_{2}$ set with $w$ for $H_{2}$. We show that $\mathcal{I}_{H}:=\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w} \cup \mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is a good set for $H$. First, $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right|=h-4$, given that $\mathcal{I}_{H_{i}}^{w}$ contains all the vertices of $H_{i}$, except for two, for $i=1,2$. Second, $u \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}$ is an ( $h_{1}-2$ )-over- $h_{1}$ set with $w$, and $v \notin \mathcal{I}_{H}$, since $\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}$ is an $\left(h_{2}-2\right)$-over- $h_{2}$ set with $w$. Third, we prove that any vertex $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H}$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$. If $z \in \mathcal{I}_{H_{i}}^{w}$ with $z \neq w$, for some $i \in\{1,2\}$, then all the neighbors of $z$ are in $V\left(H_{i}\right)$, hence $z$ has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ since it has degree at most $k$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{i}}\right]$. Also, $w$ has degree at most $h_{1}-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{1}}^{w}\right]$ and at most $h_{2}-k-3$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H_{2}}^{w}\right]$, hence at most $h_{1}+h_{2}-2 k-6 \leq h-2 k-5 \leq k$, where we used $h \leq 3 k+5$.

This concludes the proof of the theorem for the case in which $k$ is even.
If $k$ is odd, then the proof proceeds in the same way with the following differences (as a main numerical difference, the $\frac{3 k}{2}$ terms for the even case become $\frac{3 k-1}{2}$ ). First, in the base case we now have $n \leq \frac{3 k-1}{2}+3$; this case is handled with the same arguments as when $k$ is even. Second, the definition of a good set $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ for $H$ now requires $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-2$ if $k+3 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k-1}{2}+3$, requires $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-3$ if $\frac{3 k-1}{2}+4 \leq h \leq 2 k+4$ and requires $\left|\mathcal{I}_{H}\right| \geq h-4$ if $2 k+5 \leq h \leq 3 k+4$. Consequently, in statement (S2), the value of $h$ satisfies $k+4 \leq h \leq \frac{3 k-1}{2}+3$, while in statement (S3), the value of $h$ satisfies $\frac{3 k-1}{2}+4 \leq h \leq 3 k+4$. Statements (S1)-(S3) then imply the statement of the theorem, by setting $\ell=\frac{3 k-1}{2}+2$. In particular, note that $\ell+2=\frac{3 k-1}{2}+4$ and $2 \ell+1=3 k+4$; these are the smallest and largest values of $h$ in statement (S3). The reason why we need to settle for a smaller ratio, namely $\frac{2 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3}$ rather than $\frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$, when $k$ is odd is that missing three vertices in a graph with at least $\frac{3 k-1}{2}+4$ vertices is not good enough for the ratio $\frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$, while it is for $\frac{2 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3}$. Indeed, $\frac{(3 k-1) / 2+1}{(3 k-1) / 2+4}=\frac{2 k+2 / 3}{2 k+14 / 3}<\frac{2 k+1}{2 k+5}$. The proof of the statements (S1)-(S3) proceeds almost verbatim with respect to the case in which $k$ is even. In the proof of statement (S2), we used $h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ in order to prove the inequality $h-k-1 \leq k$ (and the weaker inequalities $h-k-3 \leq k$ and $h-k-2 \leq k$ ). With $h \leq \frac{3 k-1}{2}+3$ rather than $h \leq \frac{3 k}{2}+3$ such inequality is obviously still satisfied, since the left term is smaller than before. Also, in the proof of statement (S3), we used $h \leq 3 k+5$ in order to prove that the degree of $w$, which is upper bounded by $h-2 k-5$, is smaller than or equal to $k$. Again, since now $h \leq 3 k+5$, the

degree of $w$ is still smaller than or equal to $k$.
This concludes the proof of the theorem.

# 4 Induced Subgraphs of Planar Graphs 

In this section, we consider the size of the largest induced subgraph of degree at most $k$ that one is guaranteed to find in an $n$-vertex planar graph. Table 3 shows the coefficients of the linear terms in the size of the induced subgraphs we can find, for various values of $k$.

![table_2](table_2)

Table 3 Results on planar graphs with different values of $k$.
We start by proving two upper bounds, the first one, $\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+O(1)$, is tighter for $k<10$, while the second one, $\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+O(1)$, is tighter for $k>10$.

- Theorem 7. For every $n \geq 1$ and for every integer $k \geq 3$, there exists an $n$-vertex planar graph $G$ with the following property. Let $\mu=\min \left\{\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+5, \frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2\right\}$. Consider any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. Then $|\mathcal{I}| \leq \mu$.

Proof. We distinguish two cases, depending on which of $\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+5$ and $\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2$ is smaller.

Figure 7 Illustration for Theorem 7. (a) The graph for the case $\mu=\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+5$, with $n=21$, $k=3$, and $h=3$. (b) The graph for the case $\mu=\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2, n=21, k=3$, and $h=3$ (values of $k$ for which $\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2<\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1}$ are too large to result in a readable figure).

Suppose first that $\mu=\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+5$. Let $G$ be the $n$-vertex planar graph depicted in Figure 7(a) and defined as follows (note that $G$ contains the graph from the proof of Theorem 1 as a subgraph). Let $h=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2 k+1}\right\rfloor$. Then $G$ contains a path $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{2 h}$, vertices $u_{1}^{i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{i}$, for $i=1, \ldots, 2 h$, and edges $u_{j}^{i} u_{j+1}^{i}, v_{i} u_{j}^{i}, v_{i-1} u_{1}^{i}$, and $u_{k-1}^{i} v_{i+1}$, whenever the end-vertices of such edges are in $G$. The graph also contains vertices $w_{1}, w_{3}, \ldots, w_{2 h-1}$, where $w_{2 i-1}$ is connected to $v_{2 i-2}$ (if $i>1$ ), to $v_{2 i-1}$, to $v_{2 i}$, to $v_{2 i+1}$ (if $i<h$ ), and to $u_{1}^{2 i-1}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i-1}, u_{1}^{2 i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i}$. Additional $n-h \cdot(2 k+1)$ isolated vertices, which do not play any role in the proof of the statement, are added to $G$, so that it has $n$ vertices.

Consider any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. We prove that there exists a set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, such that $\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right|=|\mathcal{I}|$, and such that $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ does not contain any of $w_{1}, w_{3}, \ldots, w_{2 h-1}$. Suppose that $\mathcal{I}$ contains a vertex $w_{2 i-1}$, for some $i \in\{1, \ldots, h\}$. Then there exists a vertex $z$ among $u_{1}^{2 i-1}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i-1}, u_{1}^{2 i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i}$, that is not in $\mathcal{I}$, as otherwise $w_{2 i-1}$ would have degree $2 k-2$, which is larger than $k$ since $k \geq 3$. Replace $w_{2 i-1}$ in $\mathcal{I}$ with $z$. Clearly, the size of $\mathcal{I}$ remains the same. Also, $G[\mathcal{I}]$

still has degree at most $k$. Indeed, suppose, for a contradiction, that a vertex $z^{\prime}$ has degree larger than $k$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$. Then $z^{\prime}$ is either $z$ or a neighbor of $z$, given that $z^{\prime}$ either is not in $\mathcal{I}$ or is in $\mathcal{I}$ and has degree at most $k$ before the replacement. If $z^{\prime}=z$, it suffices to observe that $z^{\prime}$ has degree at most 4 in $G$, and one of its neighbors, namely $w_{2 i-1}$, is not in $\mathcal{I}$ after the replacement. If $z^{\prime}$ is a neighbor of $z$, then $z^{\prime}$ is a vertex among $v_{2 i-2}$ (if $i>1$ ), $v_{2 i-1}, v_{2 i}, v_{2 i+1}$ (if $i<h$ ), and $u_{1}^{2 i-1}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i-1}, u_{1}^{2 i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{2 i}$. However, all such vertices are neighbors of $w_{2 i-1}$, hence the degree of $z^{\prime}$ in $G[\mathcal{I}]$ does not increase after the replacement. The repetition of this replacement results in the desired set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$.

From the set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$, a set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime}\right]$ has degree at most $k$, such that $\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime}\right|=\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right|$, and such that $\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime}$ does not contain any of $w_{1}, w_{3}, \ldots, w_{2 k-1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{2 k-1}$ can be constructed as in the proof of Theorem 1. Indeed, suppose that $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ contains a vertex $v_{i}$, for some $i \in\{2, \ldots, 2 h-1\}$. Then there exists a vertex $z$ among $u_{k-1}^{i-1}, u_{1}^{i}, u_{2}^{i}, \ldots, u_{k-1}^{i}, u_{1}^{i+1}$ that does not belong to $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$, as otherwise $v_{i}$ would have degree $k+1$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$. Replace $v_{i}$ in $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ with $z$. Clearly, the size of $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ remains the same. Also, $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$ still has degree at most $k$. Indeed, no vertex among $w_{1}, w_{3}, \ldots, w_{2 k-1}$ belongs to $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$. Also, every vertex $u_{j}^{\ell}$ has degree at most 4 in $G$ and has one neighbor among $w_{1}, w_{3}, \ldots, w_{2 k-1}$, which is not in $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$, hence the degree of $u_{j}^{\ell}$ in $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$ is at most 3 . Finally, $z$ is a neighbor of $v_{i}$, which however is not in $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$ after the replacement, and might be a neighbor of $v_{i-1}$ or $v_{i+1}$. However, $v_{i-1}$ or $v_{i+1}$ are also neighbors of $v_{i}$, hence if they are in $\mathcal{I}^{\prime}$, their degree in $G\left[\mathcal{I}^{\prime}\right]$ does not increase. The repetition of this replacement results in the desired set $\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime}$.

Note that $\left|\mathcal{I}^{\prime \prime}\right| \leq n-(2 h-2)-h=n-3\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2 k+1}\right\rfloor+2 \leq n-\frac{3 n}{2 k+1}+5=\frac{2 k-2}{2 k+1} n+5$.
Suppose next that $\mu=\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2$. We define a planar graph $G$ as follows, see Figure 7(b). Let $h=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{k+4}\right\rfloor$. Initialize $G$ to a cycle with $n-2 h$ vertices, labeled $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n-2 h}$. For $i=1, \ldots, h$, insert into $G$ two vertices $v_{i}$ and $w_{i}$, which are adjacent to the $k+2$ vertices $u_{j}$ such $(i-1) \cdot(k+2)+1 \leq j \leq i \cdot(k+2)$.

Consider any set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. For $i=1, \ldots, h$, we have that, among the $k+4$ vertices $v_{i}, w_{i}, u_{(i-1) \cdot(k+2)+1}, \ldots, u_{i \cdot(k+2)}$, at least two do not belong to $\mathcal{I}$. Indeed, if at least $k+1$ among $u_{(i-1) \cdot(k+2)+1}, \ldots, u_{i \cdot(k+2)}$ belong to $\mathcal{I}$, then neither $v_{i}$ nor $w_{i}$ belongs to $\mathcal{I}$, as otherwise $G[\mathcal{I}]$ would contain a vertex of degree at least $k+1$. It follows that $|\mathcal{I}| \leq n-2 h=n-2\left\lfloor\frac{n}{k+4}\right\rfloor \leq n-2 \frac{n}{k+4}+2=\frac{k+2}{k+4} n+2$.

We now focus our attention on the lower bound. We present an algorithm, called PlanarGreedyRemoval, that given a planar graph $G$ and a target integer value $k \geq 3$, defines a large set of vertices $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$. As the name suggests, the algorithm follows a natural greedy strategy: It repeatedly removes from the current graph $\mathcal{G}$ (initially, we have $\mathcal{G}=G$ ) any vertex with maximum degree, until $\mathcal{G}$ has the target degree $k$. When this happens, the set of vertices of $\mathcal{G}$ is the desired set $\mathcal{I}$.

In order to get better bounds, we tweak this strategy a bit if $k=3$ or $k=4$. In these cases, once $\mathcal{G}$ has degree $k+1$, we augment $\mathcal{G}$ to a $(k+1)$-regular graph, in which we find a small dominating set $\mathcal{D}$. We remove from $\mathcal{G}$ the vertices in $\mathcal{D}$. Now $\mathcal{G}$ has degree $k$ and its vertex set is the desired set $\mathcal{I}$. We choose the strategy that removes the smallest number of vertices. This algorithm is the basis for the following theorem.

- Theorem 8. For every $n \geq 1$, for every planar graph $G$ with $n$ vertices, $m$ edges, and degree $d \geq 4$, and for every integer $3 \leq k \leq d-1$, there exists a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ and such that:

1. if $d=4$ and $k=3$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{7}{13} n-\frac{24}{17}$;
2. if $d=5$ and $k=3$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{35}{18} n-\frac{8}{13}$;
3. if $d \geq 6$ and $k=3$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{10}{13} n-\frac{5}{39} m-\frac{8}{13} \geq \frac{5}{13} n+\frac{2}{13}$;

4. if $d=5$ and $k=4$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{9}{11} n-\frac{1}{2}$;
5. if $d \geq 6$ and $k=4$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{23}{59} n-\frac{3}{59} m-\frac{35}{59} \geq \frac{27}{58} n+\frac{19}{59}$; and
6. if $d \geq 6$ and $k \geq 5$, then $|\mathcal{I}| \geq n-\frac{m}{k+1} \geq \frac{k-2}{k+1} n+\frac{6}{k+1}$.

Proof. Before delving into the analysis of PlanarGreedyRemoval, we introduce some notation. A simple, yet crucial, observation is that the degree of the current graph $\mathcal{G}$ does not decrease throughout the algorithm execution. For any $i=d, d-1, \ldots, k$, we let $\mathcal{G}_{i}$ be the graph $\mathcal{G}$ the first time it has degree at most $i$; thus, $\mathcal{G}_{d}=G$ and $\mathcal{G}_{k}$ is the graph whose vertex set is $\mathcal{I}$. It is possible that $\mathcal{G}_{i}=\mathcal{G}_{i-1}$; this happens if removing vertices of degree $j$ from $\mathcal{G}_{j}$, for some $j \geq i+1$, the degree of $\mathcal{G}$ drops to $i-1$, or lower. We denote by $r_{i}$ the number of vertices of degree $i$ that are removed by PlanarGreedyRemoval; these are the vertices that are in $\mathcal{G}_{i}$ and not in $\mathcal{G}_{i-1}$. Also, we denote by $r_{6}^{i}$, the sum $\sum_{j=6}^{d} r_{j}$, that is, the number of vertices of degree at least 6 that are removed by PlanarGreedyRemoval.

We are now ready to analyze PlanarGreedyRemoval. In order to do so, we distinguish the six cases in the theorem's statement.

Case 1: $d=4$ and $k=3$. We show that $G=\mathcal{G}_{4}$ can be augmented to a 4 -regular, not necessarily planar, graph by adding at most 6 vertices, and several edges, to it. While there exist two vertices that are not adjacent and that both have degree smaller than 4 , we add an edge between them. When no such an edge can be added, the vertices of degree smaller than 4 induce a clique $K_{x}$ in $\mathcal{G}_{4}$. Then it suffices to add at most 6 vertices (and some further edges) to $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ in order to obtain a 4-regular graph $\mathcal{H}_{4}$, see Figure 8. Every $h$-vertex 4-regular

Vertices and edges in $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ are black, while vertices and edges in $\mathcal{H}_{4}$ and not in $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ are gray. graph has a dominating set of size at most $\frac{4}{11} h$ [25], hence $\mathcal{H}_{4}$ has a dominating set $\mathcal{D}$ of size at most $\frac{4}{11}(n+6)$. Let $r_{4}$ be the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ that are in $\mathcal{D}$. Removing such vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ results in a graph $\mathcal{G}_{3}$ with degree at most 3 . We thus get the following:

$$
r_{4} \leq \frac{4}{11}(n+6)
$$

The vertex set of $\mathcal{G}_{3}$ is our desired set $\mathcal{I}$, where $|\mathcal{I}|=n-r_{4} \geq \frac{7}{11} n-\frac{24}{11}$.
Case 2: $d=5$ and $k=3$. The algorithm first removes $r_{5}$ vertices from $G$ obtaining $\mathcal{G}_{4}$, and then removes $r_{4}$ vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ resulting in $\mathcal{G}_{3}$, whose vertex set is $\mathcal{I}$. We upper bound $r_{4}+r_{5}$ in two different ways. First, by Equation (1) and since the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is $n-r_{5}$, we get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5} \leq \frac{4}{11}\left(n-r_{5}+6\right)+r_{5}=\frac{4 n+7 r_{5}+24}{11}
$$

Second, the number of vertices of degree 4 that are removed from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is at most $\frac{1}{4}$ times the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$, since the removal of a degree- 4 vertex removes 4 edges from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$. Also, the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is equal to the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$, which is at most $\frac{5 n}{2}$ given that $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ has degree 5 , minus 5 times the number of vertices of degree 5 that are removed from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$. Hence, we get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5} \leq \frac{\frac{5 n}{2}-5 r_{5}}{4}+r_{5}=\frac{5 n-2 r_{5}}{8}
$$

We thus get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5} \leq \frac{43}{78} n+\frac{8}{13}
$$

Equation (4) comes from Equation (2) when $r_{5} \leq \frac{23 n}{78}-\frac{32}{13}$ and from Equation (3) when $r_{5} \geq \frac{23 n}{78}-\frac{32}{13}$. Therefore, it follows that $|\mathcal{I}|=n-r_{4}-r_{5} \geq \frac{32}{78} n-\frac{8}{13}$.

Case 3: $d \geq 6$ and $k=3$. The algorithm first removes $r_{6^{+}}$vertices from $G$ to obtain $\mathcal{G}_{5}$, then removes $r_{5}$ vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ to obtain $\mathcal{G}_{4}$, and finally removes $r_{4}$ vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$, resulting in $\mathcal{G}_{3}$, whose vertex set is $\mathcal{I}$. We upper bound $r_{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}}$in three different ways. First, by Equation (4) and since the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ is $n-r_{6^{+}}$we get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{43}{78}\left(n-r_{6^{+}}\right)+\frac{8}{13}+r_{6^{+}}=\frac{43 n+35 r_{6^{+}}+48}{78}
$$

Second, by Equation (1) and since the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is $n-r_{5}-r_{6^{+}}$, we get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{4}{11}\left(n-r_{5}-r_{6^{+}}+6\right)+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}}=\frac{4 n+7 r_{5}+7 r_{6^{+}}+24}{11}
$$

Third, as in Case 2, the number of vertices of degree 4 that are removed from $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is at most $\frac{1}{4}$ times the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$. Also, the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is at most the number $m$ of edges of $G$, minus 5 times the number of vertices of degree 5 that are removed from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$, minus 6 times the number of vertices of degree at least 6 that are removed from $G$. Hence, we get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{m-5 r_{5}-6 r_{6^{+}}}{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}}=\frac{m-r_{5}-2 r_{6^{+}}}{4}
$$

We thus get:

$$
r_{4}+r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{3}{13} n+\frac{5}{39} m+\frac{8}{13}
$$

Equation (8) comes from Equation (5) when $r_{6^{+}} \leq-\frac{5}{7} n+\frac{2}{7} m$, from Equation (6) when $r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq-\frac{19}{91} n+\frac{55}{273} m-\frac{32}{13}$, and it comes from Equation (7) when $r_{6^{+}} \geq-\frac{5}{7} n+\frac{2}{7} m$ and $r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \geq-\frac{19}{91} n+\frac{55}{273} m-\frac{32}{13}$. The last implication is justified by observing that, for any fixed value of $r_{5}+r_{6^{+}}$, the quantity $\frac{m-r_{5}-2 r_{6^{+}}}{4}$ is maximized by choosing $r_{6^{+}}$ as small as possible, i.e., equal to $-\frac{5}{7} n+\frac{2}{7} m$. Then the value of $r_{5}$ which maximizes $\frac{m-r_{5}-2 r_{6^{+}}}{4}$ is $-\frac{19}{91} n+\frac{55}{273} m-\frac{32}{13}-\left(-\frac{5}{7} n+\frac{2}{7} m\right)=\frac{46}{91} n-\frac{23}{273} m-\frac{32}{13}$. It follows that $|\mathcal{I}|=n-r_{4}-r_{5}-r_{6^{+}} \geq \frac{19}{13} n-\frac{5}{39} m-\frac{8}{13} \geq \frac{5}{13} n+\frac{2}{13}$, where the last inequality follows from the fact that $m \leq 3 n-6$.

Case 4: $d=5$ and $k=4$. This case is similar to Case 1. Namely, we augment $G=\mathcal{G}_{5}$ to a 5 -regular, not necessarily planar, graph by adding at most 7 vertices, and several edges, to it. This is done by first adding edges between pairs of non-adjacent vertices whose degree is smaller than 5 . When this is not possible, the vertices of degree smaller than 5 induce a

(h) $x=2$, one deg- 3 vertex and one deg- 1 vertex. (i) $x=2$, one deg- 4 vertex and one deg- 1 vertex. (j) $x=2$, two deg- 2 vertices. (k) $x=2$, one deg- 3 vertex and one deg- 2 vertex. (l) $x=2$, one deg- 4 vertex and one deg- 2 vertex. (m) $x=2$, two deg- 3 vertices. (n) $x=2$, one deg- 4 vertex and one deg- 3 vertex. (o) $x=2$, two deg- 4 vertices. (p) $x=3$, three deg- 2 vertices. (q) $x=3$, one deg- 3 vertex and two deg- 2 vertices. (r) $x=3$, one deg- 4 vertex and two deg- 2 vertices. (s) $x=3$, two deg- 3 vertices and one deg- 2 vertex. (t) $x=3$, one deg- 4 vertex, one deg- 3 vertex, and one vertex of degree 2. (u) $x=3$, two vertices of degree 4 and one deg- 2 vertex. (v) $x=3$, three deg- 3 vertices. (w) $x=3$, one deg- 4 vertex and two deg- 3 vertices. (x) $x=3$, two deg- 4 vertices and one deg- 3 vertex. (y) $x=3$, three deg- 4 vertices. (z) $x=4$, four deg- 3 vertices. (aa) $x=4$, one deg- 4 vertex and three deg- 3 vertices. (ab) $x=4$, two deg- 4 vertices and one deg- 3 vertex. (ac) $x=4$, three deg- 4 vertices and three deg- 3 vertices. (ad) $x=4$, four deg- 4 vertices. (ae) $x=5$, five deg- 4 vertices.
clique $K_{x}$ in $\mathcal{G}_{5}$. Then it suffices to add at most 7 vertices (and some further edges) to $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ in order to obtain a 5 -regular graph $\mathcal{H}_{5}$, see Figure 9. Every $h$-vertex 5 -regular graph has a dominating set of size at most $\frac{5}{14} h$ [34], hence $\mathcal{H}_{5}$ has a dominating set $\mathcal{D}$ of size at most $\frac{5}{14}(n+7)$. Let $r_{5}$ be the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ that are in $\mathcal{D}$. Removing such vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ results in a graph $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ with degree at most 4 . We thus get the following:

$$
r_{5} \leq \frac{5}{14}(n+7)
$$

The vertex set of $\mathcal{G}_{4}$ is our desired set $\mathcal{I}$, where $|\mathcal{I}|=n-r_{5} \geq \frac{9}{14} n-\frac{1}{2}$.
Case 5: $d \geq 6$ and $k=4$. The algorithm first removes $r_{6^{+}}$vertices from $G$ obtaining $\mathcal{G}_{5}$, and then removes $r_{5}$ vertices from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ resulting in $\mathcal{G}_{4}$, whose vertex set is $\mathcal{I}$. We upper bound $r_{5}+r_{6^{+}}$in two different ways. First, by Equation (9) and since the number of vertices of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ is $n-r_{6^{+}}$, we get:

$$
r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{5}{14}\left(n-r_{6^{+}}+7\right)+r_{6^{+}}=\frac{5 n+9 r_{6^{+}}+35}{14}
$$

Second, the number of vertices of degree 5 that are removed from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ is at most $\frac{1}{5}$ times the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$, since the removal of a degree- 5 vertex removes 5 edges from $\mathcal{G}_{5}$. Also, the number of edges of $\mathcal{G}_{5}$ is at most the number $m$ of edges of $G$, minus 6 times the number of vertices of degree at least 6 that are removed from $G$. Hence, we get:

$$
r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{m-6 r_{6^{+}}}{5}+r_{6^{+}}=\frac{m-r_{6^{+}}}{5}
$$

We thus get:

$$
r_{5}+r_{6^{+}} \leq \frac{5}{59} n+\frac{9}{59} m+\frac{35}{59}
$$

Equation (12) comes from Equation (10) when $r_{6^{+}} \leq-\frac{25}{59} n+\frac{14}{59} m-\frac{175}{59}$ and from Equation (11) when $r_{6^{+}} \geq-\frac{25}{59} n+\frac{14}{59} m-\frac{175}{59}$. Therefore, it follows that $|\mathcal{I}|=n-r_{5}-r_{6^{+}} \geq \frac{54}{59} n-\frac{9}{59} m-\frac{35}{59} \geq$ $\frac{27}{59} n+\frac{19}{59}$, where the last inequality follows from the fact that $m \leq 3 n-6$.

Case 6: $d \geq 6$ and $k \geq 5$. The number of vertices of degree at least $k+1$ that are removed from $G$ is at most $\frac{1}{k+1}$ times the number of edges of $G$, since the removal of a vertex with degree at least $k+1$ removes at least $k+1$ edges from $G$. Hence, we get:

$$
\sum_{j=k+1}^{d} r_{j} \leq \frac{m}{k+1}
$$

Therefore, it follows that $|\mathcal{I}|=n-\sum_{j=k+1}^{d} r_{j} \geq n-\frac{m}{k+1} \geq \frac{k-2}{k+1} n+\frac{6}{k+1}$, where the last inequality comes from the fact that $m \leq 3 n-6$.

Using Theorem 8, we can get better lower bounds for sparse families of planar graphs. For example, $n$-vertex planar graphs that admit a planar drawing in which every face has degree at least $g$ (these include planar graphs of girth at least $g$ ) have at most $\frac{g(n-2)}{g-2}$ edges by Euler's formula, and hence have a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$ and such that $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{(25 g-60) n-14 g+48}{39(g-2)},|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{(35 g-108) n-17 g+70}{59(g-2)}$, and $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{(g k-2 k-2) n+2 g}{(g-2)(k+1)}$ if $k=3, k=4$, or $k \geq 5$, respectively, by Theorem 8. As a notable implication, $n$-vertex bipartite planar graphs have a set $\mathcal{I} \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most 3 and such that $|\mathcal{I}| \geq \frac{20}{39} n-\frac{4}{39}$, which is strictly larger than the maximum size of an induced linear forest $[14]$.

# 5 Conclusions 

In this paper, we initiated the study of large induced graphs of bounded degree in classes of planar graphs. For any integer $k \geq 3$, we presented upper and lower bounds for the value of the function $f_{k}(n)$ such that every $n$-vertex outerplanar or planar graph has an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with $f_{k}(n)$ vertices. Our upper bounds are existential, while our lower bounds are universal and are based on polynomial-time algorithms that compute the desired graphs. An obvious direction for further research is to close the gaps between the upper and lower bounds we presented. See again Table 1 in Section 1 for a numerical comparison of our upper and lower bounds for the case $k=3$.

We believe that our techniques have the potential to yield further improvements on the considered problems, as explained below.

Let $c_{k}$ be the maximum value such that every $n$-vertex outerplanar graph $G$ has an induced subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with $c_{k} \cdot n+o(n)$ vertices. We believe that the use of Lemmas 3 and 4 that was done in order to prove Theorems 5 and 6 could be

![img-13.jpeg](img-13.jpeg)

Figure 10 An $n$-vertex 4 -regular planar graph in which repeatedly removing degree- 4 vertices might result in the removal of $\frac{n}{2}-O(1)$ vertices. The removed vertices are large disks.
stressed further, in order to prove a lower bound of the form $d_{k} \cdot n+O(1)$ for the size of a set $\mathcal{I}$ such that $G[\mathcal{I}]$ has degree at most $k$, where $d_{k}$ is arbitrarily close to $c_{k}$. Indeed, by employing "very large" values of $\ell$ in Lemma 3, the numerical effect of the constraint imposed by Lemma 4 of excluding two vertices, namely $u$ and $v$, from the set of vertices $\mathcal{I}_{H}$ that induce a large subgraph $G\left[\mathcal{I}_{H}\right]$ with degree at most $k$ in the $u v$-split subgraph $H$ of $G$ becomes negligible. We plan to use this intuition to experimentally determine the value $c_{k}$, for small values of $k$, up to some decimal digits. In particular, it would be interesting to understand whether $c_{k}$ is equal to $\frac{k-1}{k}$, which would match our upper bound from Theorem 1. Theorem 5 proves that $c_{k}=\frac{k-1}{k}$ is indeed the right bound for $k=3$. Also, we suspect that these techniques could be extended to find large induced subgraphs of bounded degree in graphs of bounded treewidth.

In order to find large induced subgraphs of degree at most $k$ in a planar graph $G$, we employed a greedy algorithm which repeatedly removes a vertex with maximum degree, until the graph has degree at most $k$. For $k=3$ and $k=4$, we modified the algorithm so that the vertex removal stops when $G$ has degree at most $k+1$. Then $G$ is augmented so that it becomes $(k+1)$-regular. Finally, $G$ achieves degree at most $k$ by the removal of a small dominating set, for which we have good upper bounds on the minimum size [25, 34].

It is worth remarking that the greedy algorithm without the dominating set strategy still produces a lower bound better than $\left\lceil\frac{n}{4}\right\rceil$, which is the size of a linear forest that one is guaranteed to find in $G$ [28]. However, for the case in which $d=4$ and $k=3$, it only gives us an $\frac{n}{4}$ lower bound, see Figure 10, which is worse than the $\frac{7 n}{11}$ lower bound we get by using the dominating set strategy, see Theorem 8; consequently, not employing the dominating set strategy leads to worse bounds also for $d=5$ and $d \geq 6$.

Observe that the degree of a planar graph can be reduced to $k$ by repeatedly applying the dominating set strategy, each time decreasing the degree of the current graph by 1 . This approach does not seem to lead to good bounds for our problem.

We deem interesting to understand whether it is possible to achieve bounds smaller than $\frac{4 n}{11}$ and $\frac{5 n}{14}$ on the size of a dominating set by exploiting the planarity of the graph. In fact, our desired sets do not even need to be dominating, but only need to dominate the degree- 4 vertices, that is, every degree- 4 vertex should be in the set or adjacent to a vertex in the set. Finally, we ask whether one could obtain lower bounds better than ours for $k \geq 5$ by using known results on the size of dominating sets in $(k+1)$-regular graphs [4].

Acknowledgments. Thanks to Ross J. Kang and Michael J. Pelsmajer for pointing out to us relevant literature for the problem we studied.

abstract:
In this paper, we study the following question. Let $\mathcal G$ be a family
of planar graphs and let $k\geq 3$ be an integer. What is the largest value
$f_k(n)$ such that every $n$-vertex graph in $\mathcal G$ has an induced
subgraph with degree at most $k$ and with $f_k(n)$ vertices? Similar questions,
in which one seeks a large induced forest, or a large induced linear forest, or
a large induced $d$-degenerate graph, rather than a large induced graph of
bounded degree, have been studied for decades and have given rise to some of
the most fascinating and elusive conjectures in Graph Theory. We tackle our
problem when $\mathcal G$ is the class of the outerplanar graphs or the class
of the planar graphs. In both cases, we provide upper and lower bounds on the
value of $f_k(n)$. For example, we prove that every $n$-vertex planar graph has
an induced subgraph with degree at most $3$ and with $\frac{5n}{13}>0.384n$
vertices, and that there exist $n$-vertex planar graphs whose largest induced
subgraph with degree at most $3$ has $\frac{4n}{7}+O(1)<0.572n+O(1)$ vertices.
